reviewText: I actually saw this when it was first aired on TV, so when I realized I could get it on DVD, I had to have it to add to my Christmas collection of films for the holiday.  Every year I watch a set of some 20 films at Christmas time that has become a personal tradition.  Not all of them are specifically about the holiday, but many of them are set during Christmas or are about the underlying spirit of the holiday.  For me the Grinch is very much part of that.The DVD version appears--at least to me--much as it did when it first came out.  The cartoon setting is very minimalist in character, in keeping with the tradition of animation during the 60s as developed by Hannah Barbara, for cartoons like Yogi Bear and Huckelberry Hound, and in stark contrast to some of that featured earlier in the genera, like Mickey Mouse, the Old Farmer, and others.  The setting is less cluttered with detail, and features broad blocks of color that give an impression of content and emotive character and delight the eye.  There is not the slightest attempt at creating "reality," which makes the magic of the story acceptable even to the most pragmatic.Boris Karloff does the narrative and is the speaking voice of the Grinch.  They couldn't have selected a better actor for the role.  My mother once told me that a record company that featured stories for children had asked the man to narrate some of them, but that they had so scared the children that they failed miserably.  She said she saw him once when we lived in California, and he seemed like a lovely, grandfatherly old gentleman who wouldn't scare a fly!  This combination of the scary voice and the lovely, old grandfather seems to come across brilliantly in his narration of the Grinch story.The music is simple and memorable.  Who can't remember at least a few lines of "You're a Mean One Mr. Grinch?"  The poetry by Suess is wonderful, well rhymed and tempoed work with wildly improbable words and great pairs of lines that give punch to the meaning of the words.My favorite character is and always has been the little bewildered dog.  How cute.  That single much pruned horn tied to his head to make him look like a "reindeer" is just wonderful, especially when viewed frontally!  And his manful and surprisingly successful attempts to move the huge sleigh uphill in deep snow is also delightful.  I'd watch the film just for the little dog!Especially for young children, the rather unthreatening "villain," his reclamation at the end, and the underlying theme that Christmas "doesn't come in a bag" makes the Grinch a wonderful choice for family holiday films.
summary: I'd watch it just for the little dog!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Great fun, especially since I tend to root for the Grinch! Actually, I have a lot of sympathy for him. His first and abiding complaint was that the Who children made too much noise playing with their new toys. Since we all know the story so well ("You've got garlic in your soul, Mr. Grinch"), I just want to make a couple of observations from the special features.Surely you noticed that the narrator was Boris Karloff, and also that he did the voice of the grinch. But did you know that the marvelous song, "You're a Mean One Mr. Grinch" was sung by Tony the Tiger? True! Or at least by the same voice actor who did Tony. Had you caught the fact that Cindy Lou Who has antennae, but not the rest of the Whos?And had you caught the fact that in this movie, Christmas is an entirely secular holiday? There is nothing even remotely religious about it.I won't say watching this has put me in the Christmas spirit. Rather, I will say that it reinforced my own grinchiness. And I have no intentions of stealing anyone's gifts or decorations or roast beast.
summary: The Origin of the War on Christmas

reviewerName: Edward Hancock II "Edward Hancock II, Author ...
reviewText: As a child of 4 or 5 years old, watching this, I have to say that Boris Karloff's rendering of the Grinch gave me literal nightmares. But then I always loved a movie that could enter my slumber, so even the nightmares of my childhood were a welcome adrenaline rush.I realize this is a movie you're probably only supposed to watch at Christmas time, but honestly I can watch it in the middle of July and enjoy it just as much as if I I were watching it on Christmas Morning!When I was a kid, it was about the lesson learned by the Grinch. He learned to let people in, to love and to be loved. He learned the true meaning of being a cheerful giver.As a grown-up, it's about being able to harken back to a simpler time. About re-living those moments I so enjoyed in my youth. The Grinch is more than a holiday classic. It's a journey into one of the most enjoyable aspects of a person's past.It's beautifully drawn... as I already said, the voices are positively mesmerizing. The message/moral/theme is very positive and clear. Tell me what's NOT to like about this movie?

reviewText: ". . . Now, please don't ask why. No one quite knows the reason. It could be, perhaps, that his shoes were too tight. Or it could be that his head wasn't screwed on just right. But I think that the most likely reason of all is that his heart was two sizes too small."And that's maybe the reason why the Grinch makes Ebenezer Scrooge look like Elmo. This is absolutely one of the greatest Christmas classics to have ever been created. The plot is simple: the Grinch hates Christmas, so he decides to steal it away from the townsfolk. The animation is quite above average compared to others, but I don't think that's the point. I do admire the animation here even if it isn't really that great, but the story of the Grinch is what I admire most about the film. This is a tale about the uselessness of greed and the true meaning of Christmas. The film itself is excellent. It's half an hour long, but it never feels rushed. It has some very humorous moments, as well as some astonishing voice work from Boris Karloff. The only minor problem I have with this film is the song that's sung by the citizens of Whoville, which can get a bit annoying (but at least it's not THAT annoying). Overall, everyone must see How the Grinch Stole Christmas during the holiday season. It's a lovable Dr. Seuss adaptation will surprisingly make you feel warm and comfortable during this final month of the year.
summary: "The Grinch hated Christmas, the whole Christmas season."

reviewText: In the peaceful town of Whoville, the Whos young and old love christmas with all their hearts except one furry green yet very cold hearted miser named The Grinch (Voiced by Boris Karloff) who loathed Christmas the most. He decides that he must stop christmas from coming as he uses his dog Max to help him impersonate Santa Claus for on Christmas eve he begins to rob everything of the Whos including the Roast Beast but later he discovers there's more to Christmas then just gifts and something more.One of the most beloved animated specials of all time! ever since it's debut in 1966, it has became an annual holiday tradition over the years for TV networks. Boris Karloff both narrates the special and even voices the Grinch as he was perfectly casted for the role, June Foray whom you all know as Rocky from "Rocky and Bullwinkle" voices Little Cindy Lou Who. The animation from Chuck Jones is incredible even today as this special is timeless all the way even with it's message that it gives out to the viewer.This DVD contains briliant picture and sound thanks to the remastering! it also includes the original 1970 "Horton Hears a Who" and extras include Featurettes, Biography gallery, song selection, "TNT's How the Grinch Stole Christmas" documentary with Phil Hartman, and Grinch Pencil Test.
summary: One of the greatest Yuletide specials ever!

reviewText: Sure, the green is a little "off", when you compare it to the TV version.  It looks like they took a very old dull colored movie, and made the colors more clear and clean in attempt to update the look.  It isn't drastic.  If you want the old look then you should probably get the VHS or an old DVD.  But if you want it to look as clear as it can (you are paying extra for the "blu-ray" aren't you?) on your HD TV, then this is the way to get it.Like I said, the color change isn't drastic, and the colors are not hard on the eyes or fluorescent or anything, they are just a tad deeper and vibrant.  It was probably one of the few things they could do to make this old film worthy of the blu-ray label.About the movie, if you have not seen it, then you should watch it. It is short and great for all ages, especially kids and kids at heart.

reviewText: At this point in time, most everybody reading this review has seen "The Grinch" countless times on their TV machines. So the only question that need be asked of this BluRay version is this: is it worth upgrading to if I already own the DVD?The answer to that question is a resounding "YES!" -  the BD transfer is excellent, the best I've ever seen. The colors are true, the picture is clear and sharp, and all of the annoying glitches that plagued this show in its previous releases are long gone. The soundtrack is a bit improved from the DVD version, but as seems to be the case with many BDs produced from a mono sound source, the same care that is lavished on updating the video component of the film isn't lavished on the soundtrack.These years, "The Grinch" shows up on TV multiple times during the holiday season. One can't help but catch it at some point, either through normal TV viewing or by taping it to DVR for later viewing. Which makes ownership of the physical product less of a necessity than it was back in the decades when the film got one broadcast on one network on one specific day at one specific hour.Still, it's nice to have it sitting on the shelf...

reviewText: My son loves the Grinch, which explains why we've watched a Grinch-related cartoon every single day up to Christmas (and, if I were to guess, beyond that).  Since I have seen the cartoon more times than I've watched any other movie in my life, I thought it was time I review it.Only now can I appreciate the creative dream team behind the Grinch: the legendary cartoon director Chuck Jones, whimsical child author Ted Geisel (Dr. Seuss), and horror icon Boris Karloff.  Yes, that Boris Karloff, the horror icon who often collaborated with Bela Lugosi on a wide range of Universal horror films.  In person, Karloff was actually very kind to children and even dressed up as Father Christmas to hand out presents at a Baltimore hospital.  It's fitting his legacy is a beloved children's classic.The story begins with the Grinch, who lives in his mountain home with his dog Max. The Whos down in Who-ville sing lovely Christmas songs that are quite catchy.  But the Grinch's real beef with them is the noise. He decides to stop the madness by dressing up as Santa Claus and stealing every single piece of paraphernalia he can find.========================" That's one thing I hate! All the noise, noise, noise, noise!"--The Grinch====================As an adult it's hard to blame the Grinch; he's not so much complaining about the Who Christmas spirit but rather their toys.  And that's the brilliance of Dr. Seuss' story.  Children look at the Grinch as a mean old anti-Santa, while adults feel a twinge of sympathy for the old guy who has been putting up with this nonsense for years. The Grinch is definitely one of us.======="Why, for fifty-three years I've put up with it now. I must stop Christmas from coming... but how?" - The Grinch=======There's a mythological origin for the hairy green guy up in the mountains.  His name is Krampus, and although he has a lot in common with the Grinch he's also considerably more demonic, with horns and hooves, a long tongue, and a switch he uses to beat bad children and carry them away.  And here we thought Santa was mean when he left coal in your stocking! The Grinch, in much the same fashion, "steals Christmas" from those who are undeserving dressed as the jolly old elf himself.After watching it enough times you begin to really appreciate Jones' direction.  The Grinch has all the comedic timing of Bugs Bunny and Wile E. Coyote, and his facial expressions are at turns hilarious (the lip twitch is a Jones trademark) and emotive.  The entire cartoon is blocked out like a movie, with unconventional camera views frequently staring up at the Grinch.  There was no need to remake this as a live action film; Jones treated his subject with the expertise of a movie director.Karloff's voice, both as narrator and the Grinch, is pitch-perfect.  Who better to play a monster turned kind than a kind man who played monsters? Karloff's voice acting is best when he's complaining about the Whos and, at the end, bewildered by their insistence on still celebrating Christmas despite their lack of baubles.And finally there's Dr. Seuss' incomparable writing. The story never diverges too far into nonsensical words. Despite its simple message, it's never too preachy.  The only allusion to religion is the sparkling star that forms in the center of the Who circle and rises up into the nighttime sky.  It beautifully, simply, conveys the spirit of Christmas without beating you over the head with it.  Accompanied by uplifting chorus and Karloff's cheerful narrative, it's easy to fall in love with this cartoon the fifty-fourth time you see it.==========="He hadn't stopped Christmas from coming, it *came*! Somehow or other... it came just the same."===========

reviewText: I'm going out on a limb and assuming you already saw "How The Grinch Stole Christmas", have watched it more times than you can count and perhaps even have a copy already.  So, your only question is, "Is it worth buying the Deluxe Edition?"I vote "yes"...in direct proportion to how much you love this classic.  If you're a big fan like I am, it's worth every penny.  The colors are sharp and clear and bring out the great art  and color choices involved in putting together the animation.  The soundtrack is also sharp and clear. If you're not a big fan, and already ok with the multiple airings in the holiday season, then there is no reason to get the DVD.I'm not as big a fan of "Horton Hears a Who", and so am not as personally excited about the remaster.  However, again, if you're a big fan, it will be most welcome.The extras are all standard fare of the making of "How the Grinch Stole Christmas". Good for about one viewing every year.But the real reason to buy this DVD is the beloved Grinch, Max, the Who's (especially Little Cindy Lou Who, that's who), Boris Karloff's narration, the songs, etc, etc, etc, <SIGH>Merry Merry everyone!!
summary: So Is It Worth Buying the Remastered Edition?

reviewText: This is likely the most known part of television for both Dr. Seuss and animator Chuck Jones. I can see why with the first, but the latter achieved even more, I feel, with both of Rudyard Kipling's stories "Rikki Tikki Tavi" and "Mowgli's Brothers", back in the mid 70s. However, this special definitely has its moments of brilliance. For one, Boris Karloff is the narrator (and is GREAT) and, also, Thurl Ravenscroft (voice of Tony the Tiger of Kellogg's Frosted Flakes cereal) is irreplaceable in performing the theme song. This is by far not the best of the classic Christmas programs, but is definitely in the top ten. On the other hand, it is the preferred filmed version - and then some - of the story. DO NOT waste your time with the worthless Ron Howard film adaptation, starring Jim Carrey, which makes, literally, the top 10 worst Christmas film list (if you don't believe me, Google this and see how many agree).
summary: One of the Christmas Classics of TV

reviewText: Wow! I just watched this newest edition of the Grinch, and what a difference! The COLORS are FABULOUS! He never looked better! The remastering is, well, masterful; and I never saw this wonderful Christmas feature so beautifully represented.All the hundreds of times I watched this before have been in B&W; by comparison!"You're a Mean One-Mr Grinch! You have Termites in your Soul!"Sung by the inimitable Thurl Ravenscroft (what a great name!) who also voiced one of the Ghosts on the Haunted Mansion ride, ( a Singing Bust in the Graveyard) lends a thrilling richness to the feature, as great as the voice of Boris Karloff as the Grinch himself.An extra feature on this disc is the Making of...including interviews with Mrs Theodore Geisel, AKA Mrs Seuss, and Chuck Jones, who worked closely with his old friend Dr Seuss, at first reluctant to animate his story, but who thawed after seeing the drawings and hearing the great songs, esp the one on Christmas Morning.Horton hears a Who is included, and this is just wonderful...so sweet.One day Dr Seuss was sitting at his desk littered with sketches when a breeze wafted in and blew a drawing of an elephant onto a drawing of a tree, which set Seuss to thinking: "What is that elephant doing up in that tree?" which led to Horton Hatches the Egg.Seuss's wonderful surrealist POV is the child's version of Dali, and another favorite Seuss work of mine is the sets he created for "The 5,000 Fingers of Dr T."This set also includes Phil Hartman's Grinch special and pencil tests.But the real star here is the incredible colors and how magnificent the Grinch looks in his splendid coat of bright Green. You've never seen this great feature so beautifully done until you get this version! The packaging is wonderful with sparkles all over the jacket.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Scotman's Film & Book Reviews "Film & Book Re...
reviewText: I Must Keep Christmas From Coming!I rented the 2006 anniversary edition of the classic Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas.  The voice-over of Boris Karloff was as creepy as ever.  The "Tony Tiger" voice of Thurl Ravenscroft (uncredited!)  singing "You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch" was enjoyable.The Grinch and his poor dog Sam, who goes along with the Grinch's scheme - oh, what a foul one, Mr. Grinch!  And the Whos down in Who-ville unsuspectingly get ready for Christmas but even as the Grinch steals all their material possessions, the Whos down in Who-ville actually embrace and sing together anyway.Great themes of even the worst of us has a heart (even if it is two sizes too small!) and that Christmas is more than just "stuff" but is people and an interactive group and makes itself evident when we sing and enjoy each other's company - even as we eat the Roast Beast!Features:The DVD was rich with features, including the composer and songwriter who put the songs together, interviews with the wife of Dr. Seuss (Theodor Seuss Geisel) and a chat with Chuck Jones, the master of Looney Toons.  There were several "making of" the feature, from the more recent Chuck Jones interview to the older, corny TCM version!  I enjoyed how they worked the children into the interviews to show that Seuss's art of storytelling is timeless.We also get to enjoy Horton Hears a Who, another Seuss/Jones collaboration but is really for kids only as it was a pale story compared to "Grinch."Highly recommended!DVD Features include (per Amazon.com):Grinch Song Selections:-"Opening Song"-"Trim Up the Tree"-"Welcome, Christmas"-"You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch"-Whos Who in Whoville - Bio on all your favorite Grinch team with Creator/Writer Theodore (Dr. Seuss) Geisel; Director, Chuck Jones; Narrator, Boris Karloff; and The voice of Cindy-Lou, June Foray-Grinch Pencil Test-TNTs "How The Grinch Stole Christmas" Special Edition - A historic look at the Grinch with the late Phil Hartman as he takes you through the production team-Songs in the Key of Grinch - Featurette on the songs and voices inside of this famous movie-"Making Animation and Bringing it to Life" audio commentary with animator Phil Roman and June Foray

reviewText: The greatest Holiday animated special of all-time, "How The Grinch Stole Christmas" holds a place in people's hearts who first saw the special airing back in the sixties. Now thanks to DVD a whole new generation of kids can see this wonderful Christmas classic. Originally airing on December 18, 1966 on CBS, "How The Grinch Stole Christmas" tells the tale about the lonely Grinch who lives hundreds of feet above Whoville in an old decrepit cave with his dog Max. He is determined to streal Christmas from the Whos thinking that people only love the Holidays for the commercial aspect of it all. The Grinch soon discovers the true meaning of Christmas as his heart grows by two sizes. Boris Karloff, a famous horror-movie actor from the 1940's, narrates the story and supplies the voice of the Grinch. I am in my early thirties and every year I pop in this little DVD along with "The Judy Garland Christmas Show". I then know the Holidays have started. The DVD of "How The Grinch Stole Christmas" comes with audio commentary by animator Phil Roman and June Foray who supplied the voice of Cindy Lou, "who was no more than two". There is also an informative interview with award-winning composer Albert Hague and vocalist Thurl Ravenscroft. Simply, a marvel to be enjoyed by the whole family!
summary: "I Must Stop Christmas From Coming...But How?"

reviewText: I was a child over 50 years ago when I first delighted to the story of Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas.  I grew up on Dr. Seuss story books, I loved The Cat In The Hat, The Cat In The Hat Comes Back, Horton Hears A Who and my special favorite Green Eggs & Ham.  I drove my mom crazy reading Green Eggs & Ham to all who would listen.  Being an autistic child most animated stories were too complex for me to follow in my earliest ages.  I don't understand it but Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas immediately made perfect sense to me.  I liked the Grinch because like me he did not like people and being autistic in this strange brother did I understand the Grinch on that score.  Like me the Grinch hated THIS CHRISTMAS FILLED WITH NOISE, NOISE, NOISE SO MUCH NOISE!So again the grinch and I shared common ground in that we both hated NOISE.  In the biginning of the story viewers were supposed to hate the Grinch because; he was so painfully antisocial but I had found a friend.  The Grinch lived in his cave away from people with his little dog which I would consider my ideal living situation.  So like always the non autistic social meaning of How The Grinch Stole Chrismas was lost to me so it might appear.  However having identified so deeply with the grinch before his transformation, when the story turned and the grinch became a good guy I understood his motives.I both understood why the grinch was the antisocial way he was before his transformation and I also understand why he chose to transform himself into a better more humane being.  Watching Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas helped me develop my Autistic Werewolf persona where I would transform as needed to survive in this common sense noise and people filled society.  This Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (Deluxe Edition)  is well done and the colors are intense.  the sound was awesome on my systems at home.  Best of all Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (Deluxe Edition) brings back grand memories in a part of my life devoid of any really awesome memories. My autistic childhood was one spent alone with few great memories Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas was one of the shining lights of joy in my childhood.  Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (Deluxe Edition) reminds me of one of my childhoods few outright joys.
summary: A CHILDHOOD FAVORITE LOOKING VERY GOOD GIVEN ITS AGE.

reviewText: No Christmas season would be complete without seeing this classic of classics. Most of us know the story, so I won't get into that here, but rather want to comment on how well this special is scripted. First of all, it's in perfect rhyme, which makes it that more interesting. Next, I love how the Grinch is depicted as a bad guy, all the while jokingly poking fun at him with one memorable line after another: "you've got garlic in your soul", "you've got termites in your smile", "you're as cuddly as a cactus", etc., which culminates in the "stink, stank, stunk" line that has become part of pop culture. One thing that jumps out at the viewer is the Grinch's cruelty toward animals (namely his dog). While this can touch a nerve, it's nevertheless who the Grinch is (or was), so I've never heard a public backlash regarding this. With the classic Christmas specials come special messages, and in this one, it's about having a heart, having forgiveness, and having a sense of community and love over material things. I highly recommend this DVD.
